Answer: The issue you're experiencing is likely due to the fact that you're reading the entire input stream into a single byte array. This can lead to performance issues, especially if the data being sent is large.

To resolve this, you can use a DataInputStream to read the data in smaller chunks. Here's how you can modify your ReadData class in the server:

```java
public class ReadData extends Thread {
    private DataInputStream inputStream;

    public ReadData(Socket socket) throws IOException {
        this.inputStream = new DataInputStream(socket.getInputStream());
    }

    public void run() {
        try {
            byte[] data = new byte[1024]; // Adjust the buffer size as needed
            int bytesRead;
            while ((bytesRead = inputStream.read(data)) != -1) {
                System.out.println("[" + System.currentTimeMillis() + "] Server has read, " + new String(data, 0, bytesRead) + ", details: " + socket.getLocalAddress().getHostName() + ":" + socket.getLocalPort());
                server.parsePacket(data, 0, bytesRead, socket.getInetAddress(), socket.getPort());
            }
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}
```

In this modified version, the read method returns the number of bytes read, which allows you to create a new byte array of the appropriate size and pass it to the parsePacket method. This way, you're only reading and processing the data that's actually available, which should improve performance.

Please note that you'll need to adjust the buffer size and the parsePacket method call in the server code to match the new parameters.
